A couple of weeks later, when faced with more opportunities to give and share, the children were much more generous after their character had been praised than after their actions had been. Praising their character helped them internalize it as part of their identities. The children learned who they were from observing their own actions: I am a helpful person. This dovetails with new research led by the psychologist Christopher J. Bryan, who finds that for moral behaviors, nouns work better than verbs. To get 3- to 6-year-olds to help with a task, rather than inviting them âto help,â it was 22 to 29 percent more effective to encourage them to âbe a helper.â Cheating was cut in half when instead of, âPlease donât cheat,â participants were told, âPlease donât be a cheater.â When our actions become a reflection of our character, we lean more heavily toward the moral and generous choices. Over time it can become part of us.
